scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-108 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-108 is a star with 1.25 times the mass of the Sun, and 2.19 times its radius. It is located 4101.18 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3.89 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-108 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-108 system


Kepler-108 b

Kepler-108 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.29 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-108 b is 55.968 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-108 b is 8.650 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-108 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


Kepler-108 c

Kepler-108 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.72 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-108 c is 50.880 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-108 c is 8.180 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-108 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-108, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-108 - System With 2 Exoplanets
